What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: I developed a strong understanding of American political institutions.
Definitely got a better overview of the literature! I also became better at analyzing methodology.

I learned how various models worked and how well they applied to different dynamics in our politics today and throughout history. I learned how to evaluate different research designs and different trends in political science today (bandwagoning on audit studies).

I learned a large degree on congressional theory, the ideology of legislators, and spatial theories explicating policy decision-making. I gained the skill of being able to observe and analyze spatial theories with more precision and accuracy.
Useful overview of the literature, good discussions on both methods and substance
Greatly increased my knowledge of American political institutions and the political science research on them.  Gained skills in analyzing this research.

A better understanding of how to think about the "equilibrium outcome" of the institution we see (e.g., Congress, the bureaucracy) and how the incentives and preferences of the actors with the power (e.g., the median member) would cause this equilibrium result. Also gained an enhanced understanding of spatial models. Also an enhanced ability to think through some research designs.
Kelly is an excellent professor. She is very kind and explained complicated material very clearly.
I enjoyed the readings and the format of the papers; it allowed enough flexibility week by week while still encouraging the synthesis of ideas.

Maybe one week where we read studies that all do one kind of statistical analysis method (diff in diff week, etc.) to clarify when a technique is used well compared to when it's not? But I did like how the readings were grouped by subject areathat may have been at the expense of greater understanding of statistical methods.

A weakness of the course was that it did not pose specific discussion questions and key aspects of readings to look for. A strength of the course is that we were encouraged to tie the readings from past weeks to current readings.

I liked the balance in the readings, between classical pieces and more recent work, and between formal models and more empirical work. 
The "mini-lectures" when a topic deserved them were often useful.

The strengths were the syllabus and instructor.  I enjoyed most of the readings and the discussions had in class.  The only real weakness was that sometimes the in-class discussions were a little slow.

Strength: Read lots of different material
Weakness: I didn't love the 1-pagerssometimes they felt like busy work; I also never seemed to engage with the readings when writing essays as much as Kelly wantedmaybe some clearer directions at the outset could've helpedit seems a function of trying to write similar papers for prior courses for this course, but the past kinds weren't quite good enough for Kelly (which seems awesomewe should be pushed); sometimes I wanted class discussion to be more structured
I would recommend this course to any student interested in obtaining a better understanding of how America's political institutions operate.
Yes! Take this course if you want a crash course on the literature on institutions in various corners of American politics.
Yes if they were in the same position as me with the BA / MA
Yes, I would recommend this course to students that are looking to get a good overview of institutional theory regarding the Senate, House of Rep, state constituencies.
I would recommend this class to someone who was interested in the fine details of American political institutions.
Yes, to anyone interested in American politics or the political economy of institutions.
Yea definitely. It was helpful to think through why institutions form, how they persist, and the implications of their designfor different kinds of cases/environments.
